title: Question 2
content:
An object moves at constant velocity for a period of time, after which it undergoes uniform deceleration until it comes to rest. A velocity-time graph is plotted for this motion. On the graph, which of the following would represent the displacement of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Gradient of the line connecting the initial and final velocities.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ x-intercept
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ y-intercept
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Area under the graph
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For option A, the gradient of the line connecting the starting and ending velocities gives the average acceleration.
For option B, x-intercept represents the time of when velocity is zero, therefore is incorrect.
For option C, y-intercept represents the velocity when the time is zero, therefore is incorrect.
For option D, area under the graph is the displacement, which is the correct answer.

title: Question 6
content:
A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of $1.5$ m above the ground. What is the maximum height reached above the ground if the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s$^{-1}$?  (Take $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$)


- A. $\hspace{1em} 0.45$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em} 1.50$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em} 1.95$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em} 6.00$ m
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1: 
Maximum height occurs when the final speed $v$ is zero. The height reached above hand


- $\begin{aligned}
  \ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
  \ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
  \ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
  \end{aligned}$

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

Solution 2: 
Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion


- $\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh$
- $\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h$
- $h=0.45$ m

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

title: Question 12
content:
An object moves 9 m east, then 12 m north.
What is the magnitude of the total displacement of this object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 3 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 21 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 36 m
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Through vector addition,
Displacement = $\sqrt{12^2+9^2}=$ 15 m
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e50b399f-ba85-45b3-9d7a-2d74e67e1d12/images/dc7fbbc7-404a-4ee4-a92a-16430a6afe38/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.15.26%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

title: Question 13
content:
A car moves clockwise in a circular path as shown. The direction of its instantaneous velocity at two different times is shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/21aa0775-c02f-42e9-9634-13951995f288/PH0496.png)


Which of the following vectors shows the direction of the change in velocity?
A.$\hspace{3cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/88b7624f-0886-4115-8256-99af940a2b46/PH0496A.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/85315f05-4867-40f4-be2d-ccc71a187238/PH0496B.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/7fa46ed6-98b1-4454-aee3-ef279b9768b9/PH0496C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/675b5d83-2283-4319-be39-7fd0e6705a2d/PH0496D.png)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in velocity = final velocity - initial velocity = $v_2 + (-v_1)$. In a vector diagram, we represent $-v_1$ as in the opposite direction to the $v_1$ direction, and then add the vectors $v_2$ and  $(-v_1)$ as shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/d52701ff-7d73-457d-a85d-d5d2fb5dd7fe/PH0496-1.png)

title: Question 15
content: - Define distance. [1] - An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distance d with time t is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/ec0aad4a-2afd-42a6-8ebe-1a8af181242f/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.47.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - Describe the motion of the object between $t=0.5$ s and $t=1.0$ s. [1] - Calculate the instantaneous speed of the object at $t=0.5$ s. [2] - On the axes below, sketch a possible graph of the variation of velocity $v$ of the object with time $t$. There is no need to add values to the axes. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/c787d9d0-d867-4d03-980d-27f4c5fbad95/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.50.32%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Determine the direction of the change in momentum of the object during the motion. [2]
markScheme:
- Length of the path followed $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - Slows down/decelerates $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The slope of the graph gives the speed of the object. The slope decreases between $t=0.5$ s and  $t=1.0$ s. Therefore the object slows down.
    
  - Any evidence for drawing tangent at $t=0.5\, s$ $\checkmark$
    $\ll\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=\gg18\pm2\, m\,s^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/db214a2c-2e68-4bce-8a9a-e0cd2cc8719c/Screenshoot%202025-07-02%20at%202.52.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


    The gradient of the tangent line =$\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=18$ m s$^{-1}$
    
  - A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient $\checkmark$
    Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/4ba5e265-a440-45f1-81d9-62bf89b670e0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.30.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.
    The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.
    
  - The final momentum is less than the initial momentum $\checkmark$
    Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentum $p_f$ is less than the initial $p_i$ momentum. The change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    
    
    - $\Delta p=p_f-p_i$

    since $p_i$ > $p_f$, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

title: Question 17
content:
A football player kicks a ball initially at rest. The ball reaches a speed of 36 km h$^{-1}$ in a time of 0.5 s. Which of the following is the acceleration of the ball in terms of the gravitational acceleration, $g$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.2$g$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$g$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$g$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 7$g$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Converting 36 km h$^{-1}$ to m s$^{-1}$:


- 36 km h$^{-1}=\dfrac{36000\ \ce{m}}{3600\ \ce{s}} = 10\ \ce{ m s}^{-1}$

Acceleration is $\dfrac{\textrm{change\ in\ velocity}}{\textrm{change\ in\ time}}$
therefore


- $a=\dfrac{10}{0.5} = 20$  m s$^{-2}$

Approximating $g$ to be 10 m s$^{-2}$, the correct answer is  $2g$.

title: Question 20
content:
A student throws a ball with an initial velocity in the horizontal direction. Air resistance is negligible. At $t = 2.0$ s, the ball has travelled a distance $x$ in the horizontal direction and a distance $y$ in the vertical direction.
What are the horizontal and vertical distances covered at $t = 1.0$ s, in terms of $x$ and $y$?

Horizontal distanceVertical distance$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{2}$ $\dfrac{y}{4}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{2}$ $\dfrac{y}{2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{4}$ $\dfrac{y}{2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{4}$ $\dfrac{y}{4}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Horizontal velocity is constant, therefore, the distance travelled will be half in half the time.
Vertical height is proportional to $t^2$ ($s=\dfrac{1}{2}at^2$) therefore if time is divided by 2, height will be divided by $2^2$ = 4.

title: Question 22
content:
A train, initially at rest, accelerates steadily at $1.0$ m s$^{-2}$. The distance $s$ travelled during each successive second, for the first five seconds of its motion, was recorded in meters. Which of the following correctly represents the distance covered in each successive second?
(Diagram is not to scale)

$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/a83f3eae-d161-4a41-9f8f-d22606e464ef/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.18%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/386b2086-8e1c-4e9e-bf4a-6231d750be7b/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.23%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/fc9e005d-60a8-4f17-a00f-1e4d7de3be39/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.28%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/c2df3d3a-dfd6-4210-ae9f-73009dd848b2/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since the question requires values of distance and provides values of initial velocity, acceleration and time, use a suitable kinematics equation to determine the distance travelled from 0 - 1 s, 0 - 2 s, 0 - 3 s, 0 - 4 s, and 0 - 5 s.
Then find the distance travelled during each second by subtraction (Subtract distance traveled in first second from distance traveled on first two seconds, etc.)
Compare your values of distance for each second with the choices given to determine the most suitable choice.
1$^{\textrm{st}}$ second: $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(1)(1)^2 = 0.5$ m
Time 0 to 2: $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(1)(2)^2 = 2$ m (distance traveled 1.5 m)

title: Question 23
content: - - Define acceleration. [1] - A car is moving on a straight road. The variation of the car's velocity $v$ with time $t$ is seen in the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/89d74bbe-f554-4361-83e3-86838d4d2316/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.18.30%E2%80%AFAM.png) Describe, in terms of acceleration, the motion of the car. [2] - A truck with a speed of 20 m s$^{-1}$ passes by a stationary car. The car starts to move with an acceleration of 4 m s$^{-2}$ just as the truck goes past. Both of the vehicles move in the same direction. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/a2c4a308-86fe-4749-8457-388fdd6baf59/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.20.52%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - Show that the time needed for the car to overtake the truck is 10 s. [3] - On the graph below, draw the variation in speed $v$ of both vehicles with time $t$ during the first 10 seconds of the motion and comment about the areas under the graphs without calculation. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/244e46d9-6793-400d-a64e-03bc982e8300/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.43.13%E2%80%AFPM.png) - In an accident scene, skid marks of a car stretching 100 m are found. According to the manufacturer of the car's tires, the deceleration that the car experiences with skidding tires is 5 m s$^{-2}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/38dc3d97-3a12-41d5-bb01-27933fb461a2/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.35.58%E2%80%AFAM.png) Determine whether the car exceeded the speed limit of 72 km h$^{-1}$. [4]
markScheme:
- 
  - Rate of change of velocity $\checkmark$
  - Accelerates at an increasing rate/increasing acceleration $\checkmark$
    Accelerates at a constant rate/constant acceleration $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The gradient of the velocity-time graph shows the acceleration of the car. Initially, the slope increases. Then the steepness of the graph is constant. Therefore, acceleration of the car increases initially then it is constant.
    

- 
  - Use of $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ for the car $\checkmark$
    Equating distances covered by both vehicles $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\ll s = 2t^2 = 20t \gg$
    - $\ll t^2 = 10t \gg$
    - $t =$ 10 s $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
Since they are at the same position initially, the car has to cover the same distance as the truck in the same time interval. The car accelerates uniformly which enables us to employ suvat equations. The distance travelled by car for a time of $t$;
    
    
    - $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ where $u = 0$ and $a = 4$ m s$^{-2}$

    Therefore;
    
    
    - $s = \dfrac{1}{2} (4)t^2 = 2t^2$

    The truck moves at a constant speed. Hence, its distance for the time of $t$;
    
    
    - $s = vt$
    - $s = 20t$

    When both of the distances are equated;
    
    
    - $s = 2t^2 = 20t$
    - $t^2 = 10t$
    - $t = 10$ $s$

  - Straight line $\checkmark$
    Starts from (0,0) and ends at (10,40) $\checkmark$
    Horizontal line starts from (0,20) and ends at (10,20) $\checkmark$
    $\ll$ area under the graph of speed time gives distance travelled by the vehicles. Since $\gg$ they cover the same distance in 10 s according to 2 b (i)   and areas are equal/same $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/8c8caf0f-b37e-434c-86be-355597421efd/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.45.25%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The slope of a speed-time graph of an object moving in one direction is acceleration. Since the car travels with a constant acceleration, the slope of the graph should be constant. Therefore, the graph should be a straight line. The car starts from rest and its speed at $t=10$ s can be found by;
    
    
    - $v=u+at$ where $u=0$, $a=4$ m s$^{-1}$ and $t=10$ s
    - $v=0+(4)(10)=40$ m s$^{-1}$

    The speed of the truck does not change and it moves at 20 m s$^{-1}$. Its graph should be a horizontal line which has a y-intercept of 20.
    The areas under the graphs of speed-time equal to the distance covered by the vehicles. Since both of the vehicles travelled the same distance in 10 seconds according to the previous part of the question, the areas should be the same.
    

- Use of $2as=u^2$ $\checkmark$
  $u=31.6$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  Conversion of $72$ km h$^{-1}$ to $20$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  $30$ m s$^{-1} > 20$ m s$^{-1}$ and yes $\ll$ it exceeds $\gg$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The speed before pushing the brakes can be found by;
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$ where $v=0$, $a=-5$  m s$^{-2}$ and $s=100$ m

  Substitute given values in the equation;
  
  
  - $0 = u^2 + (2)(-5)(100)$
  - $0 = u^2 - 1000$
  - $1000 = u^2$
  - $u = 31.62$ m s$^{-1}$

  To compare with the speed limit, the unit of speed limit should be converted to m s$^{-1}$ or the initial speed should be converted to km h$^{-1}$
  
  
  - $\dfrac{\textrm{72 km}}{\textrm{1 h}} = \dfrac{\textrm{72000 m}}{\textrm{3600 s}} = 20$ m s$^{-1}$

  Since 31.62 m s$^{-1}$ > 20 m s$^{-1}$ the car exceeds the speed limit.

title: Question 24
content:
A small object is fired horizontally at a speed of 300 m s$^{-1}$ from the top of a building. Air resistance is negligible. The object lands 900 m from the base of the building. What is the height of the building?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 34 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 44 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 88 m
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Calculate the time taken for the bullet to land


- Speed = $\dfrac{\textrm{distance}}{\textrm{time}} \Rightarrow \textrm{time} = \dfrac{\textrm{distance}}{\textrm{speed}} \Rightarrow \dfrac{900}{300}$ = 3 s

For the vertical motion, u = 0 m s$^{-1}$, a = g = 9.81 m s$^{-2}$ , t = 3 s
Using the uniform acceleration equation:


- $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$
- $s = 0 + \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(9.81)(3)^2$
- $s = 44$ m

Note that using $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$  here gives an answer of 45 m, with the closest answer being $44$ m.

title: Question 25
content: The graph shows how the speed v of a car varies with time t. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39bef262-a62a-4d85-baac-207456cf9093/images/fe6ad622-3858-44f9-a2c1-5a9d34a15873/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%205.18.15%E2%80%AFPM.png) - State the difference between average and instantaneous accelerations. [2] - Calculate the instantaneous acceleration of the car at $t=1.0$ s. [2] - Determine, with explanation, whether the car covers more distance before or after the car reaches a constant speed. [5]
markScheme:
- Average acceleration is the change in velocity over a period of time $\checkmark$
  Instantaneous acceleration is the acceleration at a particular instant/time/point in space $\checkmark$



- Reference to the gradient of the graph = instantenous acceleration $\checkmark$
  $7.9\pm0.5\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at the interested time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn. To do this, we draw a line that represents the gradient of the curve at the exact moment when $t=1$ s. Note that this line needs to be estimated by eye, and the mark scheme will normally have an allowed range of values to account for different answers.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39bef262-a62a-4d85-baac-207456cf9093/images/304dcb46-f0c9-4a4a-a1e9-9844c3f8479d/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%205.21.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)


  The gradient of the tangent line $= \dfrac{\textrm{rise}}{\textrm{run}}=\dfrac{26.0-11.0}{1.9-0}=7.9\textrm{ m s}^{-2}$
  
- Time of reaching constant speed = 2.7 or 2.8 s $\checkmark$
  Any evidence of distance covered = area under the line $\checkmark$
  The distance covered at constant speed  $= \ \ll(25.0)(5.0-2.8)=\ \gg$ 55$\ \ll\textrm{m}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  Accept 58 m
  Any sensible estimate of the area to determine displacment before reaching a constant speed $\checkmark$
  After $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The car reaches the constant speed of $25.0$ m s$^{-1}$ at $t=2.8$ s. This is the point where the graph becomes horizontal. The area under the speed-time graph equals the car's distance travelled. The distance $d_1$ while moving at non-constant speed can be found by the method of small square approximation.
  The area of one small square =$(1.0\ \ce{m s}^{-1})(0.1 \ce{s}) = 0.1\textrm{ m}$  and the number of small squares $= 524$
  $d_1=\left(524\right)\left(0.1\right)=52.4\ $m
  The distance $d_2$ at a constant speed 
$d_2=(25)(5.0-2.8)=55$ m
  $d_2$ > $d_1$  therefore, the cover covers more distance after reaching the constant speed.

title: Question 26
content:
An object is moving in a straight line. The graph shows the variation of the velocity $v$ of the object with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9c89cf28-1ed7-42b7-a459-43d3f38fd733/images/346ccd81-3ae2-4296-9d59-33ebd8a889f0/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.18.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Consider the following statements about the graph:


- I.At point A, the object changes its direction.II.At point C the object is at rest.III.The magnitude of the acceleration at point D is greater than at point B.

Which of the statements is/are correct?


- A. I only
- B. II only
- C. I and II only
- D. II and III only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The slope of the velocity time graph gives the acceleration of the object. Therefore, at points A and D, there is no acceleration due to zero gradient. At point B, there is a negative acceleration.
Additionally, the velocity of the object at point C is as it aligns with the horizontal axis where $v=0$.
Hence, the answer is B.

title: Question 34
content:
A projectile is launched horizontally on Earth with initial speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$ from a height of $5.0$ m above the ground.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/adca8fcd-c774-446b-a421-eb944e4ddd54/images/51e584df-f2d9-4096-bc80-662140961015/PH0851aaaa.png)


What is the magnitude of the displacement of the stone when it reaches the ground?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $5.0$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $8.0$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{34}$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{51}$ m
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For the time, analyzing the vertical direction
$\hspace{1em}$ $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$
$\hspace{1em}$ $5 = \dfrac{1}{2}(10)t^2$
$\hspace{1em}$ $t = 1$ s
The horizonal displacement is
$\hspace{1em}$ $\Delta x = u_x t = (3)(1) = 3$ m
The vertical displacement from the diagram is $5$ m.
The net displacement is


- Displacement $=\sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{34}$ m

title: Question 36
content:
The graph shows the variation of speed $v$ of a ball with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13b5c41f-9e6b-4937-8397-65c5b2d2336e/images/5281444d-ae8d-4868-83f7-f80dd8085194/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.10.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The initial speed of the ball is very high. Which of the following statements could be true for the ball?


- A. It is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance.
- B. It is thrown vertically upward in the absence of air resistance.
- C. It is thrown vertically downward in the presence of air resistance.
- D. It is thrown vertically downward in the absence of air resistance.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to the graph, the ball has a decreasing deceleration and reaches terminal velocity. Since the acceleration of the ball is not constant, air resistance must be acting on the ball. Air resistance always acts in the direction opposite to the velocity.
In an upward motion, air friction and gravity are in the same direction. Therefore, it is not possible for them to cancel each other so that the ball reaches terminal velocity. It should be moving in the downward direction. Hence, the answer is C.

title: Question 40
content:
A car decelerates with a constant rate until it stops.
Which graph shows the variation of speed of the car  $v$ with the distance travelled $s$?

A.$\hspace{2cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/dc6c106f-9423-4076-af71-349a76f6d49e/PH0850aa.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/ecdf9631-dbe2-4c9e-9471-91455293b072/PH0850bb.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/7012af2d-9e8a-48b5-89f7-b121537e78be/PH0850cc.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/b643a4ae-9ad7-4081-851b-10148999bcbb/PH0850dd.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using https://www.geogebra.org/m/CtfF7SBc]}}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Note that this is a velocity-displacement graph, and so needs to be considered carefully.
Since


- $v^2=u^2+2as$

The car decelerates to stop


- $a$ is negative

Then


- $v^2=u^2-2as$

As the car moves slower, it takes more time to cover the same distance. The velocity changes at a constant rate. Therefore, each increment of distance has a larger and larger change in $velocity$.

title: Question 1
content:
The diagram below shows a tennis ball of mass $m$ striking a wall with an initial velocity, $u$, and rebounding with velocity $v$. A second, softer ball of the same mass strikes the wall with the same speed but rebounds with a slower rebound speed.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bbeffe1-fadb-4f69-a8f6-5a1deb1f20d3/images/a440cac5-43c9-4b14-97ec-4b768f633978/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.33.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following statements is correct about the magnitudes of the impulse and change in momentum applied to the second ball compared to the first?

$\hspace{1em}$  Impulse$\hspace{1em}$Change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$GreaterSmaller$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$SmallerGreater$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$GreaterGreater$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$SmallerSmaller
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in momentum and impulse applied to the ball are equal, because the impulse is defined as the change in momentum. Increasing one is the same as increasing the other and vice-versa. The slower rebound speed of the second ball causes a decrease in the magnitude of the impulse since the change in momentum is smaller if the final speed $v$ is smaller.


- $J = \Delta p = m(v - -u) = m(v + u)$

title: Question 3
content:
An object moves in a circular path of radius $2$ m with angular displacement of $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ rad in $5$ s.
What is the average linear speed of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{\pi}{20}$ m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{\pi}{10}$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{\pi}{5}$ m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\pi}{5}$ m s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The linear speed is given by


- $v=r\omega$

and


- $\omega=\dfrac{\Delta \theta }{\Delta t}$

Then:


- $v = (r) \dfrac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t} = (2) \dfrac{(\frac{\pi}{2})}{5} = \dfrac{\pi}{5}$ m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 4
content:
A skydiver of weight, $W$, of a skydiver falls through air with a drag force $F_{drag}$
If the skydiver experiences terminal velocity, which of the following best represents the free body diagram of the skydiver?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/f7d98c67-c67c-413e-b6dc-6ce1eaddd8f0/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.28%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/7e66ac3f-29ca-49cc-965b-4b1ac077eb37/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/c264232f-f4f5-4f65-b6d4-07507de5161f/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.45%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/26ffa821-04f6-4987-8f19-ab4c4a016b76/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At terminal velocity there is no accleration. Forces must be balanced, therefore the drag force is equal and opposite to the weight.

title: Question 5
content:
A car of mass $m$ and a truck of mass $3m$ travelling in opposite directions collide and stick together. The speeds of the car and the truck just before the crash are $2v$ and $v$ respectively. What is their speed after the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{1}{4}v$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{4}{5}v$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5}{4}v$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	4v $
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The vehicles move in opposite directions, therefore the total momentum before the collision is


- $m(2v)+(-3m)v=-mv$

By the principle of conservation of momentum, the momentum of the vehicles after the collision is equal to the total momentum before the collision.


- $-mv=\left(m+3m\right)v_f$

where $v_f$ is the velocity of the vehicles after the collisions.


- $v_f=\dfrac{-mv}{4m}$
- $v_f=\dfrac{-v}{4}$

Therefore the speed is $\dfrac{1}{4}v$.

title: Question 6
content:
The diagram below shows an object attached to a light inextensible string. The object is travelling in a horizontal circle at a constant speed.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1407380-c5d8-4cf6-8000-1ed0057396fd/images/86154aae-6a39-4d62-927f-7719e616b6c7/image.png)


What is the direction of the resultant force acting on the object? Select from the labeled arrows on the diagram.
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The object is moving in a circle at a constant speed so the resultant force = centripetal force. The centripetal force is directed towards the center of the circular path that the object is following. The answer is D.
There are two forces acting on the object. Weight (acting in the direction C) and tension (acting in direction A). The resultant of these two forces in the vertical plane is zero. The resultant force is the horizontal component of the tension (acting in the direction D).

title: Question 8
content:
The graph below shows the variation of the resultant force $F$ acting on a box with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9dfa696e-4fd4-4a7a-90d1-8830c669456a/PH0579q.png)


The box starts to move from rest. Which of the following graphs shows the variation of the momentum $p$ of the box with time $t$?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/71fb8624-3e7f-4803-b78f-8670d2c4c075/PH0579a.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/5df1dc95-d879-42fa-9bf5-f4a182c14b3f/PH0579b.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/10ae312c-2976-4a62-98e5-18a7efeb0dc4/PH0579c.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9fb48b7f-abee-43b9-9d28-76767fb4650b/PH0579d.png)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The area underneath of the force-time graph gives the change in momentum of the box. Since the area increases with time at a constant rate, the momentum should increase at a constant rate. The only graph that satisfies this condition is the graph in A.
Therefore, the answer is A.
Alternatively, the impulse equation gives $\Delta p = F \Delta t$ .
As $F$ is a constant,  $\Delta p$ is directly proportional to $t$ and a straight line through the origin is expected.

title: Question 9
content:
As a truck is brought to rest, the brakes apply a force of $5.1 \times 10^3$ N. Which answer best describes the magnitude of the change in momentum of the truck if the brakes are applied for 3.0 s?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $15$ kN s
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $15000$ N s
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $15.3$ kN s
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $15300$ N s
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
NOTE this question requires students to use their judgement to determine the best answer, using standard scientific conventions.


- Impulse = change in momentum =
$F \,t $

So the magnitude of the change in momentum:


- $\Delta p= (5.1 \times 10^3$)(3.0) = 15300 N s

All responses match this quantity but the number of significant figures needs to be considered. As both of the values used in the calculation have two significant figures, there should be two significant figures in the answer.
In the answer $15000$ N s, the number of significant figures is unclear. It could be 2, 3, 4 or 5. The response $15$ kN s clearly has two significant figures, so it is the best answer.

title: Question 10
content:
A football player bounced the ball off their head as shown while diving sideways:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db6d3d8f-a4f9-44a6-ac1d-3d502dc3fe03/images/625404da-8e05-4718-839c-665afe99d9b7/PH0146-1.png)


Which of the following gives a Newton's Third Law pair of forces that applies to this situation?

Force 1Force 2$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the ball on the playerForce of the ball on the earth$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the player on the earthForce of the ball on the player$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the earth on the ballForce of the ball on the earth$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the earth on the playerForce of the player on the ball
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The only combination of answers which mentions the correct Newton’s Third Law  force pair is C. In Newton’s Third Law force pairs always occur between only the same two objects.
In this case, because the ball and Earth are not in contact, it is the gravitational force that is equal and opposite here.

title: Question 11
content:
A block of wood is placed on a rough inclined surface. Which of the diagrams below correctly represents the forces acting on the block when it is at rest?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/6fd66c35-5858-47b6-b951-7ef859c5bc49/PH0261A.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/1efb7d4e-b506-4e9a-b16f-c5b29f42f15e/PH0261B.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$ $\hspace{1cm}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/d118c599-94cf-4412-bd58-11ec3f440b08/PH0261C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/371d44f4-7847-4a00-acd9-301f34fdd9b2/PH0261D.png)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Weight always acts vertically downwards
Normal reaction force is always normal (perpendicular) to the surface
In order to remain at rest, friction must act up the incline in order to keep the block from sliding down the incline under the action of the component of weight acting down the incline.
In diagram B, friction is acting down the incline. This will result in an acceleration down the incline.
In diagram C, the normal reaction is acting opposite to the weight whereas normal reaction must always be perpendicular to the contact surface.
In diagram D, weight is shown to act at an angle to the vertical, whereas weight always acts vertically downwards.

title: Question 15
content:
Two eggs of equal mass fall from the same height onto a padded floor. One of them is broken while the other one bounces upwards intact. The time of collision is the same for both. Which of the following correctly describes the egg that exerts a greater averge force on the floor and the reason?

Egg with greater average forceReason$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$BrokenGreater change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$BouncesLess change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$BrokenLess change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$BouncesGreater change in momentum
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
As the direction of motion of the bouncing egg is changed after the collision, it has a greater change in velocity than the egg that breaks. Therefore, its has a greter change in momentum.
The time of collision is the same for both situations. According to $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}$, the force acting on the egg that bounces back is greater. By using Newton’s third law, it can be stated that the average force acting on the floor from the bouncing egg is greater.

title: Question 17
content:
A jet aircraft is performing a “loop-the-loop” stunt in which it moves in a vertical circular path as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/d0824da3-0194-4631-aa10-9d3ce1dfd00f/PH00631zz.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by nnaakk from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$

Which of the following represents the free body diagram of the pilot at the top of the loop?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/4c742c4f-98f0-4d85-a677-6f1c23762946/PH0631az.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/8067d5fd-b147-485f-a09c-216f201100a5/PH0631bz.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/6feee77a-249b-4a4b-930a-4620c1310f57/PH0631cz.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/47a89b02-ad42-4196-b582-3b7bc3e63fbb/PH0631dz.png)

$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
There are two forces acting on the pilot which are the gravitational force (weight) and the normal force of the pilot's chair.
The normal force always acts from the chair onto the person. At the top of the loop, this will act vertically downwards.
The weight is always vertically downwards.

title: Question 18
content:
A stone attached to one end of a rod rotates in a vertical circle at a constant speed. Two positions of the stone at two different instants, X and Y, are shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d4352f8d-c820-4f4d-bca6-df53ec8d5067/images/791ea751-6d76-46b7-bc0b-d17159b63e87/PH0231-1.png)



In the table below, which row is correct for the centripetal force acting on the stone at X and Y?

$\hspace{1em}$ Direction of centripetal force $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1em}$Magnitude of centripetal force$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$SameSame$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$SameDifferent$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$DifferentSame$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$DifferentDifferent
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The centripetal force on an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always towards the centre of the circle therefore the direction is different at the different locations. The magnitude of centripetal force is dependent on the radius of the circular path and the speed of the object. Since both locations have the same radius and speed, the magnitude of centripetal force is constant throughout the motion. Therefore, the answer is C.

title: Question 19
content:
The diagram below shows the total upward and downward forces acting on a hot air balloon. The relative magnitudes of the forces are drawn to scale.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df4cb97a-03e0-4bd8-a84c-8dda7444c026/images/3942c2b5-5966-4703-a368-fe8f703caa1a/PH0968Edit.png)


Below are three independent statements about the possible motion of the balloon.


- I.The balloon is acceleratingII.The balloon is moving upwardsIII.The balloon is moving downwards

Which of the statements, when considered independently, could be true?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
I is correct - The diagram shows that the upward force is greater than the downward force. So, there is a net upward force acting on the balloon. $F=ma$ so there is an upward acceleration.
II could be correct – Balloon could be moving upwards - acceleration is also upwards so speed of the balloon would be increasing.
III could be correct – Balloon could be moving downwards - acceleration is upwards so speed of the balloon would be decreasing (deceleration).
For linear motion, acceleration tells us nothing about the speed, just how the speed is changing. The balloon could be moving upwards, moving downwards or stationary.

title: Question 20
content:
A car is travelling along a straight line for a total time of 100 s. Throughout this time the driving force provided by the car is 1.2 kN and the total resistive force acting on the car is 500 N.
Which row correctly shows the rate of change of momentum and the impulse of the car during the 100 s.

Rate of change of momentumImpulse$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$7 $\times 10{^2}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$7 $\times 10{^0}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$7 $\times 10{^2}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$7 $\times 10{^4}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$1.7 $\times 10{^3}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$1.7 $\times 10{^1}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$1.7 $\times 10{^3}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$1.7 $\times 10{^5}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Newton's second law states that net force = rate of change of momentum.
Therefore, the rate of change of momentum is simply the net force acting on the car


- $\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=1200$ N - 500 N = 700 N = 700 kg m s$^{-2}=7 \times 10^2$ kg m s$^{-2}$

Impulse


- $J$ = $F_{net}\Delta t$ = (700)(100) = 7 $\times$ $10{^4}$ kg m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 22
content:
A block of mass 16 kg is pushed and released along a rough horizontal surface at an initial speed of 2 m s$^{-1}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c45a6b1-fd52-47f4-87cf-51ddb2c7383c/images/0f148f8c-b290-441d-943e-e1bc0eba3a33/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.30.42%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The block travels through a distance of 16 m and is brought to rest. What is the magnitude of the frictional force that brings the block to rest?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2 N
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 4 N
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 8 N
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 16 N
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The net work done on the block 
= Change in kinetic energy of the block
$\begin{aligned}
 W_{net}&=\Delta E_k \\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 Fs \cos(\theta)& = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f)^2 - \frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\Fs\cos(\theta) &= 0 -\frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(\cos\,180^o)&=-\frac{1}{2}(16)(2)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(-1)&=-32 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
F&=2\textrm{ N}\
\end{aligned}$
Alternative:


- $v^2 = u^2 + 2as \Rightarrow a = \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2s} = \dfrac{0^2 - 2^2}{2(16)} = -0.125$ m s$^{-2}$
- $|F| = m|a| = 16|-0.125| = 2$ N

title: Question 23
content:
Two trucks X and Y are pulling a car out of thick mud along a straight path. The only other horizontal force acting on the car is a drag force opposite to the direction of motion. The diagram shows a top view of the direction of the force applied by truck $X$ and the direction of motion of the car.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/039af546-0a6a-489b-aa52-94a641645c42/images/799656dd-0ea3-431e-9ae2-ec036fc0097a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.26.09%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following vectors shows the direction of the force applied by truck $Y$?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/039af546-0a6a-489b-aa52-94a641645c42/images/af518a6b-1c74-4e1c-9e25-c26470c9ae43/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.26.19%E2%80%AFPM.png)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The motion of the car here is in the direction of the sum of the two forces vectors from $X$ and $Y$. 
The only vector that will add to vector $X$ to produce a net force vector to the right is one in the direction of C.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/039af546-0a6a-489b-aa52-94a641645c42/images/e3fe004e-d88c-4539-9390-2d8f35066f14/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.26.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

title: Question 25
content:
A rocket ejects hot gas in space in a direction opposite to its travelling direction. What is correct for the magnitude of the momentum and the kinetic energy of the rocket?

MomentumKinetic Energy$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ConservedConserved$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$IncreasedConserved$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ConservedIncreased$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$IncreasedIncreased
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The rocket is not a closed system. The reaction force from ejecting hot gas will increasingly accelerate the rocket, hence both momentum and kinetic energy will increase.

title: Question 30
content:
A car enters a roundabout with a speed $v$. The dotted line shows the path of the car. The road is slightly banked inward at an angle to the horizontal.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46047306-4c31-4e50-8ee4-a0671285fe55/images/8bef058b-da21-4259-8e52-70155256bcbb/PH0298-1.png)


The coefficient of friction between the tires of the car and the road is $\mu$. When $\mu$ decreases, which of the following changes could prevent the car from slipping away on this roundabout?

$\hspace{1em}$ Banking angle of the turn $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{3em}$ Speed of the car$\hspace{3em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$increaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$increasedecrease$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreasedecrease
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When $\mu$ decreases, the maximum possible frictional force decreases. Friction acts along with the component of the normal force in the horizontal direction to produce the centripetal force. To account for this change, decreasing the speed will allow the car to require less frictional force due to a lower required centripetal acceleration and safely take the turn.


- $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=\mu mg$

Increasing the banking angle increases the component of the normal force that points towards the centre of the circle, providing more centripetal force to compensate for the loss in centripetal force contribution from friction. Remember that in this situation friction is acting towards the centre of the circle, and so having an increased component of the normal force acting towards the centre of the circle will $\lq$help' friction to turn the car.

title: Question 32
content:
An object with a weight $W$ connected to one end of a rod of negligible mass rotates at constant speed in a vertical plane.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/51f2e4d1-787c-4b55-bf29-fb6b924bf7bd/images/3c969e82-6e66-4e40-9546-9680f77d93a8/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.50.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


When the object is at the top position of the circular path, the tension on the rod is zero. What is the magnitude of tension at the bottom position of the circular path?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Equal to $W$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Smaller than $W$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Equal to $2W$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Greater than $2W$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At the top position


- $T + W=F_{centripetal}$ and $T = 0$

Therefore,


- $F_{centripetal} = W$

At the bottom


- $T - W  =  F_{centripetal}$

Since speed is constant:


- $F_{centripetal} = W$

Therefore, the tension at the bottom


- $T = 2W$

title: Question 44
content:
A box with a mass of M rests on a balance in an elevator that is moving downwards. The elevator slows with an acceleration of   $\dfrac{g}{4}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/668949a1-7b88-4532-bf3c-3689bdf6f746/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.23.51%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following gives the reading of the balance?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5Mg}{4}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	Mg$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3Mg}{4}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{Mg}{2}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The reading of the balance is equal to the magnitude of the reaction force. The free-body diagram of the box M:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/93aad0fb-70d9-4742-9503-89c79a83c9b5/PH0543-2.png)


Since the elevator slows down downwards, the acceleration must be upwards and the normal reaction force ($F_N)$ must be greater than the weight ($F_g$). According to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:


- $F_N - F_g = ma$

When the given expressions are substituted:


- $F_N - Mg=M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)$
- $F_N = M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)+Mg$
- $F_N = \dfrac{5Mg}{4}$

Therefore, the answer is A.

title: Question 45
content:
Two blocks of masses $m$ and $2m$ approach each other and collide on a horizontal smooth surface. After the collision, they move together. The speeds of the blocks before the collision are $5v$ and $2v$ as shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f19e4d29-0626-4d4e-860f-091ac4774da8/images/e2a5e8eb-26c4-4918-8298-bcc5c293080c/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.36.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly gives the speed of the blocks after the collision and the nature of the collision?

Speed after collisionNature of collision$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $3v$Elastic$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$Elastic$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $3v$Inelastic$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$Inelastic
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to the principle of conservation of momentum, the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after the collision.
As the blocks are moving in opposite directions, a sign convention is introduced where motion to the right is positive.


- $p_{initial} = p_{final}$
- $m(5v)+2m\left(-2v\right)=3mv_f$  where $v_f$ is the speed of the blocks after the collision
- $mv=3mv_f$
- $\dfrac{v}{3}=v_f$

The initial total kinetic energy of the blocks before the collision $E_{ki}$:


- $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}m{(5v)}^2+\dfrac{1}{2}2m{(2v)}^2$
- $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(33mv^2)$

The total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collision $E_{kf}$:


- $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}(3m){\bigg(\dfrac{v}{3}\bigg)}^2$
- $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{6}mv^2$

The total kinetic energy is conserved in elastic collisions while it is not conserved in inelastic collisions.  Since the total kinetic energy before the collision is less than the total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collision, the collision is inelastic.
(In any collision where objects “stick together” the situation is an inelastic collision.)

title: Question 46
content: A solid sphere of mass $m$ is released from rest below the surface of oil and moves downwards. - Draw the free body diagram of the sphere at the instant it was released. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/5abc5ee9-e827-4a82-8625-f76a3d1c9c85/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.33.43%E2%80%AFPM.png) - - Show that the terminal speed of the sphere is given by: $v=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}$ where $\rho_s$ is the density of the sphere and $\rho_o$ is the density of oil. [2] - Another sphere from the same material but with mass $8m$ released in the oil. Determine the terminal velocity of the new sphere in terms of the terminal velocity of the smaller sphere, $v$. [3]
markScheme:
- Weight downwards and buoyant force upwards  $\checkmark$
Weight arrow is longer than the buoyant force arrow.  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The sphere is accelerating downwards. This is because the gravitational force on the sphere is bigger than the buoyant force. Note that at the instant of release, the is no velocity and therefore no drag force.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/6b72ec4a-a248-4bff-903d-3f6c8ffa03fc/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.44.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)


  
- 
  - $mg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rv$  $\checkmark$ 
Correct steps to reach $v=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}$  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
When the sphere reaches terminal speed, its weight is equal to the sum of the buoyant and drag forces.
    
    
    - $F_g=F_b+F_d$
    - $mg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rv$
    - $\rho_s Vg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rv$
    - $v=\dfrac{\rho_s Vg-\rho_o Vg}{6\pi \eta r}$
    - $v=\dfrac{Vg(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}$
    - $v=\dfrac{\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}$
    - $v=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}$

    
  - $r_2=2r$  $\checkmark$
$v \propto r^2$  $\checkmark$
$v_2=4v$  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Since the new sphere is from the same material as that in part (b) (i), then:
    
    
    - $\dfrac{m_2}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}$
    - $\dfrac{8m}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}$
    - $V_2=8V$
    - $(r_2)^3=8r^3$
    - $r_2=2r$

    From the relation in (b)(i)
    
    
    - $v \propto r^2$

    Then
    
    
    - $v_2=4v$

title: Question 47
content:
A ball of mass 100 g hits the ground at an angle of $45\degree$ and a speed of 10 m s$^{-1}$. The collision is elastic, and the ball makes contact with the ground for a total time of 100 ms. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/99fe19b1-7971-4531-bcfc-196700e2ddb3/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.03.13%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the magnitude of the average net force on the ball during the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $7.1$ N
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $10$ N
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $14$ N
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $20$ N
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}$

The horizontal component of the speed/momentum of the object does not change - the force exerted by ground is purely vertical.
Initial and final vertical velocities are $-10\sin{(45\degree)}$ and +$10\sin{(45\degree)}$ if we take upwards as the positive direction (this will give a positive force as the direction of the force exerted by the ground on the ball is upwards) see diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/67e50acf-d004-4a7b-b955-05573f43c304/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.07.40%E2%80%AFPM.png)


For the vertical direction $\Delta v=$ final velocity $-$ initial velocity $=10\sin{45\degree}-(-10\sin{45\degree})=10\sin{45\degree}+10\sin{45\degree}=20\sin{45\degree}$


- $F_{net}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{(0.1)(20\sin{45\degree})}{0.1}=20\sin{45\degree}$ = 14 N

(Here we have converted to SI units 100 g = 0.1 kg and 100 ms = 0.1 s)

title: Question 51
content: A roller coaster car with a mass of 80 kg moves on the track shown in the diagram starting from point A. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f8b40cd-a38f-4e89-a840-e407d2693c6d/images/8e2a2b25-a38d-4443-889f-8825dd14b886/PH1005_a.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https:// pixabay.com]}}$ At points B and C, the track approximates a circular path so that the radii at at B and C are 12 m and 18 m respectively. - Compare the normal force exerted by the track on the car at points B and C. [2] - Draw and label the free body diagram of the car at point C. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f8b40cd-a38f-4e89-a840-e407d2693c6d/images/ea0213e1-1751-4828-b183-089d74c0f60a/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.08.24%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Calculate the maximum speed of the car at point C so that it could remain on the track. [3]
markScheme:
- $N_B=\dfrac{mv^2}{r_B}+mg$ AND $N_C=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_C}$ $\checkmark$
  The normal force at B is greater than the normal force at C. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Resolving the forces at B
  
  
  - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r_B}=N_B-mg$
  - $N_B=mg +\dfrac{mv^2}{r_B}$

  While at C,
  
  
  - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r_C}=mg-N_C$
  - $N_C=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_C}$

  The normal force at B is greater than the normal force at C.



- 
  - .
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f8b40cd-a38f-4e89-a840-e407d2693c6d/images/a06209b9-e955-4a18-9e31-0075792f4caa/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.11.27%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    Upward normal force AND downward gravitational force. $\checkmark$
    The downward arrow is bigger than the upward arrow. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Because the car is at the top of a curve, the centripetal accleration must be towards the centre which is in the downwards direction. The accleration must also therefore be downwards, so the gravitational force must be greater than the upwards normal force.
    
  - The maximum speed is when the normal force is zero. $\checkmark$
    $v=\ll\sqrt{r_cg}\gg=\sqrt{\left(18\right)(9.81)}$ $\checkmark$
    $v=\answer{13\  \textrm{m s}^{-1}}\ \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The maximum speed at point C is when the normal force of the track on the car is zero.
    The normal force at C
    
    
    - $F_N=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_c}$

    When $F_N = 0$
    
    
    - $mg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r_c}$

    Using the given value of $r=18$ m
    
    
    - $v=\sqrt{r_cg}=\sqrt{(18)(9.81)}=13.29\textrm{ m s}^{-1}$

title: Question 54
content:
A mass $m$ is moving on a circular path at the end of a rope of constant length. The centripetal force acting on the mass is $F$.
The frequency of the motion is gradually increased.
Which graph correctly shows the change of the centripetal force $F_c$ as the frequency $f$ is increased?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/775fbf10-3bc4-4ebe-b512-ff6082e1e19e/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.18%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/5cdacb61-797f-46e1-8f53-056da57c9dda/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.23%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/08449c73-c15e-47dc-ac1c-b31237189261/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.28%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/630ba233-a848-4273-b0a6-76a57dfee62b/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In the data booklet, given centripetal acceleration:


- $a=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}$

which can also be expressed as


- $a=4\pi^2rf^2$

Since $F=ma$,


- $F=m4\pi^2rf^2$

Therefore the graph of $F$ vs $f$ must be a quadratic as in A.

title: Question 56
content:
A roller coaster car of mass $m$ approximates circular motion at point $A$ as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/10007213-04cb-4d62-9b1c-88f2b14aaab5/images/8e8ebb9e-4b0d-4aa0-a92a-3b7d7d42fb2c/PH0637.png)


The circular radius of the track curvature at point $A$ is $r$ and the track exerts a normal reaction force $F_N$ on the cart.
Which expression gives the linear speed of the cart at point $A$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{2rg}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{r(F_N-mg)}{m}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{r(mg-F_N)}{m}}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The centripetal force at point $A$ is the vector sum of the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force of the track
$\hspace{2em}$ $F_{centripetal}=mg-F_N$
And
$\hspace{2em}$ $F_{centripetal}=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$
Then
$\hspace{2em}$ $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg-F_N$
$\hspace{2em}$ $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{r(mg-F_N)}{m}}$

title: Question 59
content:
A block of mass 4.0 kg rests on an inclined plane.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/a2d8fdc5-6a82-406e-a19b-9649d2967b5c/PH0330.png)


The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane $\mu _s$ is 0.4.
Which of the following gives the angle of inclination at which the block will start to slide?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sin^{-1}(0.4)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\tan^{-1}(0.4)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\cos^{-1}(0.4)$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\tan^{-1}(0.6)$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/1ea450be-a2a5-44f8-aca9-38d06abc4237/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.09.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)




- $F_N = mg\cos\theta$
- $F = \mu_sF_N$
- $F = mg\sin\theta$
- $mg(\sin\theta) = 0.4mg(\cos\theta$)
- $\dfrac{\sin\theta } {\cos\theta}=0.4$
- $\tan\theta = 0.4$
- $\theta=\tan^{-1}(0.4)$

title: Question 60
content:
Two objects of mass $M$ and $m$ are connected via a frictionless pulley. The rope attached to the object of mass $M$ makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal. The objects are at rest.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a39026f-aa75-494c-a20c-39635e9e1fc0/images/155ede1a-26a4-4810-8047-d312bfef3356/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.43.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)


For the large mass, which expressions are correct for the force of friction F$_f$  and the normal force F$_N$?

$\hspace{3em}$ F$_f$ $\hspace{3em}$ $\hspace{4em}$ F$_N$ $\hspace{4em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \cos\theta$ $Mg - mg \sin\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \sin \theta$ $Mg - mg \sin\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \sin \theta$ $Mg - mg \cos\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \cos\theta$ $Mg - mg \cos\theta$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Resolving vertical forces on the large block:


- $F_g = F_N + T\sin \theta$

And for the large block,


- $F_g = Mg$

Substituting and solving for $F_N$ gives


- $F_N =  Mg - T\sin \theta$

Resolving horizontal forces on the large block:


- $F_f = T \cos \theta$

For the vertical forces small block


- $T = mg$

Substituting gives $F_f = mg \cos \theta$

title: Question 61
content:
Below are three suggested units for viscocity


- I.kg m$^{-1}$ s$^{-1}$II.Pa sIII.N s m$^{-1}$

Which of the unit combinations is/are correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and II
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ II and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Drag:


- $F_d=6\pi \eta rv$

By making viscosity the subject of the formula:


- $\eta =\dfrac{F_d}{6\pi rv}$

Units are substituted:


- $\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m})(\textrm{m s}^{-1})}=\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1})}=\textrm{ N s m}^{-2}$

By replacing N m$^{-2}$ = Pa:


- N s m$^{-2}$ = Pa s

By replacing N = kg m s$^{-2}$:


- $\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\dfrac{\textrm{kg m s}^{-2}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\textrm{kg m}^{-1}\textrm{ s}^{-1}$

title: Question 62
content:
A point $P$ is subjected to three simultaneous forces of magnitudes $F_A > F_B > F_C$. Point $P$ is in equilibrium. Consider of the following statements.


- I.$F_A = F_B + F_C$II.$F_A \leq F_B + F_C$III.$F_A > F_B - F_C$

Which of the statements is not always true about the magnitudes of the forces?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Vectors of forces in equilibrium form a triangle or a straight line.
The sum of two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third (II is always true).
The difference between two sides of a triangle is always less than the third (III is also always true).
I is true only when the three forces are in a straight line and $F_B$ and $F_C$ are both opposing $F_A$(not always true, as required by the question).

title: Question 66
content: A box half filled with sand is pulled by a motor at a constant speed of $2.0$ m s$^{-1}$ on a frictionless surface. During the motion, sand is added to the box from above at a constant rate of $\sigma$ kg s$^{-1}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e91a12f8-310f-42b8-a135-30c0ad0e892e/images/fb1ec50a-d277-4d69-95d5-266cdd06f303/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.45.240%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - State the condition related to the mass of an object in order for the equation $F_{net}=ma$ to be equivalent to the equation $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}$ . [1] - The force applied by the motor on the box is $0.11$ N. Determine $\sigma$. [2] - The motor has an efficiency of 75%. Calculate the total power provided to the motor. [2]
markScheme:
- Mass of the object should be constant $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum
  
  
  - $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}$

  Therefore $F_{net}$ can depend on the rate of change of mass or the rate of change of velocity or both.
  The equation
  
  
  - $F=ma$

  is equivalent to
  
  
  - $F=m\dfrac{\Delta v}{t}$

  and therefore assumes that mass is constant and that only velocity is changing with time.
  
- 
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ $\checkmark$
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}= $ $0.055\textrm{ kg s}^{-1}$  $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force $F$ applied to the box;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$

  Since $v$ is constant;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{v\Delta m}{t}$

  When $\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$ is replaced with $\sigma$;
  
  
  - $F=v\sigma$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ where $F=0.11$ N and $v=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$

  
  
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}=0.055$ kg s$^{-1}$




- Useful power output of the motor $=\ll Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=\gg 0.22$ W $\checkmark$
  The power provided to the motor $=\ll \dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = \gg $  0.29 W $ \checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The useful power output $P_o$ of the motor;
  
  
  - $P_o=Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=0.22$ W

  The efficiency of the motor;
  
  
  - Efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Input power}} \times 100\%$

  So the input power;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Efficiency}} \times 100\%$

  Substitute the given and calculated values;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = 0.29\,W$

title: Question 67
content:
Two bodies of masses 2 kg and 3 kg are connected by a thread and pulled in the upward direction with an acceleration of $g$ due to an upward force $F$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb9106b9-d99e-4523-b2e9-efa16a2c17a6/images/cbe0daf4-7e77-4429-a129-869ae3fb9bb1/PH0245q.JPEG)


The thread between the masses is cut. Which of the following is correct for the bodies just after the cut?

Acceleration of 3 kg massAcceleration of 2 kg mass$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $g$ $g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $4g$ $g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $4g$ $4g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $g$ $4g$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $F = ma$

Before the thread is cut,


- $F - W = ma$  for the system
- $W = mg = 5g    $ and  $\ ma=5g$

Therefore


- $F = 5g + 5g = 10g$

Just after the cut, the 3 kg mass is only under the influence of gravity, so its accleration is equal to $g$
The net force on the 2 kg mass is


- $F - 2g = 10g - 2g= 8g $

Acceleration of the 3 kg mass = $g$
Acceleration of 2 kg mass = $ \dfrac{8g}{2} = 4g$

title: Question 70
content:
A spherical object of radius $r$ is released from rest inside a fluid, after some time it reaches a terminal velocity $v$. The density of the fluid is $\rho_f$ and the density of the object is negligible compared to $\rho_f$. Which of the following is a correct expression for the viscosity of the fluid?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3g}{9v}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2gv}{9}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3gv}{9}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Because of the very low density of the object, in this situation it will be rising upwards through the fluid and the drag force will be directed downwards. The forces acting on the object are represented in the diagram below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fd1b8088-49d6-4cf0-a32e-2f667b767317/images/54c6d222-8e3b-49ea-a0d9-c1152711872e/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.35.15%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Weight is negligible due to the negligible object density.


- $\rho_{\textrm{object}}\ll\rho_f$
- $(\textrm{weight}=\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg\ll\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg=\textrm{buoyancy})$

When the object is at terminal velocity the net force acting on it is zero so we have:


- $\textrm{weight}=\textrm{drag force}$

Where:


- Buoyancy $=\rho_fVg$
- Drag $=6\pi\eta rv$

Where $g$ is acceleration due to gravity, $V$ is the volume of the ball, and $\eta$ is the viscosity of the liquid.


- $\rho_fVg=6\pi\eta rv$

Now substituting the volume of a sphere $V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3$ and rearranging for $\eta$ we have:


- $\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^3g=6\pi\eta rv$
- $\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^2g=6\eta v$
- $\eta=\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}$

title: Question 74
content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energy $E_p$ when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
In terms of $E_p$, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$E_p$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $E_p$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$E_p$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.25$E_p$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Using Hooke's law,


- $F=k\Delta x$

the elastic potential energy is


- $E_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta x$.

In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equation


- $F=k\Delta x$.

When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

title: Question 81
content:
A ball is falling vertically in a liquid. The overall density of the ball and the density of the liquid are the same. Which of the following is correct for the change in speed of the ball and and the direction of the acceleration?

$\hspace{1.5em}$The motion of the ball$\hspace{1.5em}$Acceleration$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Speeding upUpwards$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Slowing downUpwards$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Speeding upDownwards$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Slowing down$\hspace{1.5em}$ Downwards $\hspace{1.5em}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards.
The buoyancy :


- $F_B = {\rho}_{liquid}Vg$

Weight:


- $W=mg={\rho}_{ball}Vg$

Since the density of the ball and the liquid are the same, weight and buoyancy cancel each other and the net force acting on the ball is the drag force. Due to having upward net force while moving downwards, the ball must be slowing down. Moreover, if the initial speed was zero at the time of contact with the water, the ball would experience zero net force. The drag force provides a net upwards force, so the acceleration of the ball is upwards.

title: Question 83
content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a07393e2-13b6-4cef-b722-c8894c128a01/images/c42117b3-7ee7-46c1-b4b9-bd159e6e5cb7/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.01.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)


A cart of mass $m$ enters a smooth vertical loop the loop of radius $R$ with a horizontal speed $u$ at the bottom of the track, as shown. The cart just manages to stay in contact with the track at the top most point of its path.
Its speed at the bottom of the loop $u$, is given by:



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{5gR}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{4gR}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{gR}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{2gR}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Conservation of energy:
$E_k + E_p$ at the bottom of the circle = $E_k + E_p$ at the top of the circle.


- (I)$\hspace{0.8em}$ $\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2+0=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mg(2R)$
- $\hspace{2.2em}u^2=v^2+4gR$

Centripetal force at the top of the loop comes from the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force from the track which both point downwards, towards the centre of the circle at that point. Because the question states that the car just keeps contact with the the track, we can assume that the normal reaction force is effectively zero.
Writing Newton’s second law at that point gives:
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.7cm} mg+N &=m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
mg+0 &= m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
{v^2}&= gR \\
\end{aligned}$
Substituting this result into (I) gives


- $u^2=gR+4gR$
- $u=\sqrt{5gR}$

title: Question 90
content:
A 200 g ball is moving in a horizontal circle shown with the dotted path in the diagram. The diameter of the bowl is 40 cm and the angular speed is $4\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7a344575-2f87-453a-9f77-83741c73fc95/images/606c350c-ec49-41a6-a2c6-1c0319094817/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.56.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


What is the magnitude of the ball's centripetal acceleration?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $0.64\pi$ rad s$^{-2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	$3.2\pi$ rad s$^{-2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	$6.4\pi$ rad s$^{-2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Cannot be determined with the given information.
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The equation for the centripetal acceleration is $a_c=\omega^2r$.
Although $\omega$ is given in the question, the radius of the circular path is smaller than the radius of the bowl and no information is given to calculate it, therefore answer is D.

title: Question 95
content:
A rocket is moving in the absence of a gravitational field with constant speed. It starts to accelerate by burning fuel. At the start, the fuel contributes to most of the mass of the rocket. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed of $v$  relative to the rocket and a constant rate of $\sigma\ {kg\,s}^{-1}$. Which graph shows the variation of acceleration $a$ of the rocket with time $t$ as most of the fuel is used?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/d73b21e2-e1fb-4bf9-92cf-9ac8121ccc18/PH0583a.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/abf76f2f-87c3-412a-a029-1b61180b8190/PH0583b.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/8216d464-f854-405c-85a8-1ea9ebe0d6df/PH0583c.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/926c08c6-953b-475d-a760-ecf65928e706/PH0583d.png)
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The resultant force $F_{net}$ acting on the space rocket:


- $F_{net}=ma \hspace{2em}$

Where $m$ is the mass of the rocket at any given time.
When fuel is ejected from the rocket, it experiences a change in momentum in the frame of reference of the rocket.
A given mass $m$ of fuel has its velocity change from 0 relative to the rocket to its ejected speed of $v$.
Therefore the change of momentum of this mass of fuel is $p_2 - p_1 = mv - 0 = mv$
The force on the fuel causing this change in momentum is given by the equation
$\hspace{2em}F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{mv}{\Delta t}$
And we know that the rate of fuel ejected is
$\sigma$ which equal to $\dfrac{m}{\Delta t}$
Therefore the net force on the ejected fuel is


- $F_{net}=v\sigma$

Therefore


- $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{M}=\dfrac{v\sigma}{M}$

where $M$ is the total initial mass of the rocket and $v$ is the velocity of the ejected fuel relative to the rocket.
The mass $m_f$ of the burned fuel after the time $t$:


- $m_f=\sigma t$

The total mass of the rocket decreases over time due to burned fuel ejection, the acceleration of the rocket after the time $t$:


- $a=\dfrac{v\sigma}{\left(M-\sigma t\right)}$

According to this relationship, acceleration increases at an increasing rate. So the answer is D.
Qualitatively, the total mass of the rocket is constantly decreasing due to the ejected fuel. As the fuel is ejected at a constant rate, there is a constant net force on the rocket. With a constant net force and decreasing mass, there will be an increasing acceleration. At the start, the change in mass will have little effect on the acceleration, but over time the effect of the decrease in mass will become more and more significant and result in greater and greater acceleration.

title: Question 96
content:
A jet of water with a cross sectional area of $A$ strikes perpendicular to a wall at a speed of $v$. After the collision, the water loses all of its horizontal speed and falls to the ground. The magnitude of the force created on the wall due to the water is $F$.
Which expression give the density of the water?



- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{F}{Av^2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{F}{Av}$
- C. $\hspace{1em} 	FAv$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	FAv^2$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Considering the mass of water that strikes the wall in 1 second:


- $m=\rho V \hspace{2em}$

where $\rho$ is the density of the water and $V$ is the volume of the water.
Assigning the length of the column of water to be $l$ and cross sectional area $A$


- $m=\rho V=\rho Al$

But $l = vt$ and $t=1$, therefore $l\ =v$
Giving


- $m=\rho Av$

After the impact, the horizontal velocity of the jet is zero.


- $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\hspace{2em}$ and   $\hspace{2em}\Delta t = 1$
- $F=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{1}=m\Delta v$
$ = (\rho Av)v\ =\ \rho Av^2$

Rearranging gives


- $\rho=\dfrac{F}{Av^2}$

title: Question 100
content:
An object is swung at the end of a rigid rod in a vertical circle at a constant speed $v$ such that there is an outward tension on the rod at all times. The radius of the circle is $r$. This is illustrated in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/509a7eb6-1250-45e2-b3d2-4474aebbfe64/PH0946.png)
