The tension in the rod when the object is at its lowest point in the circle is 50% greater than the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point.
Which of the following expressions is equivalent to the acceleration of freefall on Earth, $g$?



- A. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}$
- B. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{2v{^2}}{3r}$
- C. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{v{^2}}{r}$
- D. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{3v{^2}}{2r}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Below shows a free body diagram for the object at its highest and lowest points.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/cb338b09-6560-4e28-87e1-f9046c093a52/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.54.38%E2%80%AFAM.png)


In both scenarios the object is moving in a circle therefore the net force is a centripetal force. Beccause the speed and radius are constant, the centrepetal acceleration is the same at both locations.


- $F_{net}=ma = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$

Where $m$ is the mass of the object.
(Acceleration is always towards the centre of the circle so at highest point acceleration points downwards and at highest point acceleration points upwards)
Let the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point be $T$. We are told that the tension at the lowest point is 50% higher, therefore at the lowest point the tension is $1.5T$.
Highest point:


- $T + mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$

Lowest point:


- $1.5T - mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$

Now solving these to eliminate $T$:


- $3T + 3mg = \dfrac{3mv{^2}}{r}$



- $3T - 2mg = \dfrac{2mv{^2}}{r}$

Subtracting the equations gives


- $5mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$



- $g = \dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}$

title: Question 2
content:
Which of the following units is not a unit of power?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ W
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ J
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ N m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ J s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The SI unit of power is W and it is defined as J s$^{-1}$.
Additionally, power can be calculated by


- $P = Fv$

When units of force and speed are substituted in the equation, the units become
$\hspace{1.5em}$ N m s$^{-1}$
But J is the SI unit of energy.
Therefore, the answer is B.

title: Question 3
content:
A builder uses a block and tackle pulley system to lift a bundle of materials of mass 15 kg to the top of a building of height 6 m in 9 s. What is the power delivered to the bundle? Assume $g=10$ N kg$^{-1}$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d1489c-8ba8-4cb6-8d7b-fe039bac7303/images/94315b8c-73e2-407b-bd29-9b312cbeeda6/PH0125.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0}]}$



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 W
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 17 W
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 100 W
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 900 W
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\begin{aligned}
\textrm{Power} &= \dfrac{mgh}{t}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&= \dfrac{(15\textrm{ kg})(6\textrm{ m})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})}{9\textrm{ s}}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
 &= 100\textrm{ W}\
 \end{aligned}$

title: Question 8
content:
The Sankey diagram below shows the energy degraded at different stages of a nuclear power plant.
Which of the following sections corresponds to the stage with the highest energy degradation?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db5024fd-1b28-45ad-a251-ca5baea6bb09/images/8565468f-e12a-4875-8ebe-e68ae78f9fc8/PH0139.png)
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The arrows that turn downwards represent energy degradation. The widths are proportional to the amount of energy in that stage. The widest of these is B.

title: Question 9
content:
A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of $1.5$ m above the ground. What is the maximum height reached above the ground if the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s$^{-1}$?  (Take $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$)


- A. $\hspace{1em} 0.45$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em} 1.50$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em} 1.95$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em} 6.00$ m
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1: 
Maximum height occurs when the final speed $v$ is zero. The height reached above hand


- $\begin{aligned}
  \ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
  \ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
  \ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
  \end{aligned}$

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

Solution 2: 
Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion


- $\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh$
- $\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h$
- $h=0.45$ m

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

title: Question 10
content: - State the law of conservation of momentum. [2] - A stationary body explodes into two pieces of mass as $m_1$ and $m_2$ in opposite directions. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/429bf6fe-dca5-47bd-b7e0-b199cab3baa5/images/eb3d1823-146c-4af3-9a6b-1e4afd9aafe7/PH0463.png) Just after the explosion, the ratio of the kinetic energy of $m_1$ to the kinetic energy of $m_2$ is found to be 9. Calculate the ratio of masses $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}$. [2]
markScheme:
- When the net force on a system is zero / the system is isolated $\checkmark$
  The momentum of the system does not change / the total momentum is constant $\checkmark$



- The magnitude of the momentum of the pieces is equal $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $\ll \dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9 \gg$
  - $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}\,\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Since the body is at rest, the total momentum before the explosion is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, total momentum after the collision must be zero. The two pieces move in the opposite directions. Therefore, the magnitude of momentum they possess must be the same to cancel each other. The ratio of kinetic energies;
  
  
  - $\dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9$
  - $\dfrac{m_2}{m_1} = 9$

  Therefore,
  
  
  - $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}$

title: Question 11
content:
A spring with spring constant $k$ is extended by a distance $x$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c10d0f-876b-4ad3-8025-7af70691d5b7/images/b7cb87cb-4bf9-4e63-9b30-1a5a397b29ca/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.19.25%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


$\small{\textrm{[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]}}$
The uncertainty of $k$ is 2% and that of $x$ is 3%.
What is the uncertainty of the potential energy stored in the spring?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 8%
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 11%
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 12%
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 18%
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The formula for potential energy stored is


- $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2$

Since $E_H$ is calculated from multiplying $k$ and $x^2$ (ignoring the constant $\frac{1}{2}$ as there is no uncertainty for it), then the uncertainty of $E_H$ is calculated by adding the fractional uncertainties of $x^2$ and $k$.
The fractional uncertainty of $x^2$ is double the fractional uncertainty on $x$, which gives


- $2\times3\% = 6\%$

The uncertainty of $E_P$ therefore


- 2% + 6% = 8%

title: Question 12
content:
A box of mass $m$ is pulled across a horizontal surface with a force $F$ as shown in the diagram. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the box and the surface is $\mu$. What is the energy transferred to thermal energy while a box is moved by a distance of $d$?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d68b186d-1f20-40cd-babc-b130ca4c968e/images/195ea83c-ec2e-42af-aa16-8f5e1a02e01e/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.10.31%E2%80%AFAM2.JPEG)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $Fd$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $(F-\mu mg)d$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\mu mgd$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $mgd$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Energy transferred to thermal energy will be the work done by the frictional force.


- $F_F=\mu F_N = \mu mg$  (where $F_N=mg$)
- $W = Fs = \mu mgd$

title: Question 14
content:
The engine of a racing  car provides a forward thrust of 800 N. The average of the total resistive forces acting on the car is 300 N and the car covers a distance of 1.0 km in 10 s.
What is the average power input of the engine?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^3$ W
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	8.0\times{10}^3$ W
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^4$ W
- D. $\hspace{1em}  8.0\times{10}^4$ W

title: Question 16
content:
An object of mass $2$ kg with initial kinetic energy $10$ J comes to rest as it travels a distance of $3$ m along a flat horizontal rough surface as shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/efa48de6-a923-458e-b5b0-b3f399753505/images/08aa8a00-e6f6-44bc-a347-3dcafca9cf08/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.38.35%E2%80%AFAM.png)


What is the coefficient of dynamic friction between the object and the surface?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{6}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2}{3}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Kinetic energy is transferred to work done (by friction)


- $\Delta E_K = F_f s = (\mu F_N)s =(\mu_dmg)s$

Substituting the given values leads to


- $10 = \mu_d(2)(10)(3)$
- $1 = \mu_d(2)(3)$
- $\mu_d = \dfrac{1}{6}$

title: Question 18
content: A spring of mass m is compressed against a block of mass $2m$ on a frictionless surface. The system is held stationary and the elastic potential energy stored in spring is $E_H$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04be70e3-9fb6-45cf-81d3-0066e5826298/images/ae44405c-172d-46c3-9b47-ee19e589be98/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.31.08%E2%80%AFAM.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}$ The system is released and the block and spring move horizontally. All of the elastic potential energy of the spring is converted into kinetic energy of the system. - - Show that after the system is released, the speed of the block $v_b$ is given by the equation: - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}$ [3] - The following data are given: - Mass of spring $m=120$ g - Spring constant of spring $k=85$ N m$^{-2}$ - Initial compression of the spring $x=8.0$ cm Calculate $v_b$. [2] - - The block moves onto a surface where the coefficient of dynamic friction between the block and the ground is $\mu_d=0.07$. When the block is at point $A$ its velocity is $0.71$ m s$^{-1}$. The block comes at a complete stop at point $B$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04be70e3-9fb6-45cf-81d3-0066e5826298/images/1e747ed3-6739-44b6-a508-87c8724e142b/Screenshoot%202025-06-04%20at%209.29.42%E2%80%AFAM.png) Determine the distance between $A$ and $B$. [3] - It is observed that the force required to start the block moving again is greater than the force required to keep it moving at a constant speed. Explain this observation. [1]
markScheme:
- 
  - Conservation of energy:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2_s+\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)(v_b)^2$ $\checkmark$

    Conservation of momentum:
    
    
    - $2mv_b=mv_s$ $\checkmark$

    Correct substitution and rearranging for $v_b$:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(2v_b)^2+\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)(v_b)^2$
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(6v_b)^2$
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Due to the conservation of energy, we have:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}mv_s^2+\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)(v_b)^2$
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(v_s^2+2v_b^2)$

    The initial momentum of the system is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, the magnitudes of the the two momenta will be equal:
    
    
    - $2mv_b=mv_s$
    - $2v_b=v_s$

    (working with (scalar) speeds $v_s$ and $v_b$ rather than (vector) velocities)
    Combining these equations we have:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m((2v_b)^2+2v_b^2)$
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(6v_b^2)$
    - $E_H=3m(v_b)^2$
    - $(v_b)^2=\dfrac{E_H}{3m}$
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}$

    
  - 
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(85)(0.080)^2\ll=0.272\gg$ $\checkmark$
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{0.272}{3(0.12)}}=$ 0.87 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Elastic potential energy $E_H$ is given by:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2$

    Where $k$ is the spring constant and $x$ is the extension or compression of the spring.
    Substituting in our values gives:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(85)(0.08)^2=0.272$ J

    Now substituting these values into the equation given in part (a)(i) we have:
    
    
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{0.272}{3(0.12)}}=0.87$ m s$^{-1}$

    

- 
  - 
    
    - $a=\ll-\gg\dfrac{\mu_dmg}{m}=\ll-\gg(0.07)(9.81)=\ll-\gg0.687$ m s$^{-2}$ (3sf) $\checkmark$
    - $s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37$ m $\checkmark$
    - OR

    
    
    - $\mu_dmgs=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$ $\checkmark$
    - $s=\dfrac{0.71^2}{2(0.687)}=$ $0.37$ m $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The net force acting on the block is equal to the frictional force given by:
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu_dF_N$

    Where $\mu_d$ is the coefficient of dynamic friction and $F_N$ is the normal reaction force.
    The net vertical force is zero so the normal reaction force acting on the block is equal to its weight:
    
    
    - $F_N=mg$
    - $F_f=\mu_dmg$

    Net force:
    
    
    - $F_{net}=ma$

    Where $m$ is the mass of the block and $a$ is its acceleration. The net force on the block is negative as it acts in the opposite direction to the block's velocity:
    
    
    - $ma=-\mu_dmg$
    - $a=-\mu_dg$
    - $a=-(0.07)(9.81)=-0.6867$ m s$^{-2}$

    Now for constant acceleration we have:
    
    
    - $v^2=u^2+2as$

    Where $v$ is final velocity, $u$ is initial velocity, $a$ is acceleration and $s$ is displacement. Rearranging for $s$ and substituting our values we have:
    
    
    - $v^2-u^2=2as$
    - $s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37$ m

    Alternatively, we can use conservation of energy. The block loses all its kinetic energy due to work done by friction.
    Work done by friction is given by:
    
    
    - $W = Fs$

    And the force of friction can be found from:
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu_dF_N$
    - $F_N=mg$
    - $F_f=\mu_dmg$

    Equating the change in kinetic energy to the work done by friction gives:
    
    
    - $\mu_dmgs=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$

    Solving for $s$ leads to the same equation as the other solution:
    
    
    - $s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37$ m

    
  - coefficient of static friction/ maximum static frictional force is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction/dynamic frictional force. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When an object is already in motion, the dynamic frictional force opposes its motion and remains constant. However, when the object is at rest, the static frictional force prevents it from moving.
    Static friction can take any value up to its maximum limit, which is given by:
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu_sF_N$

    where $\mu_s$ is the coefficient of static friction and $F_N$ is the normal reaction force.
    The coefficient of static friction is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction, so the maximum static frictional force is also greater than the dynamic frictional force. This means that more force is required to start on object moving from rest than is required to keep it moving at a constant speed against a dynamic frictional force.

title: Question 23
content:
Energy density is defined as the amount of energy stored in a substance per unit volume. Amounts of substances A and B are employed to supply the same average power to a city over an identical time period. The densities of these substances are $\rho$ and $2\rho$, respectively, with their respective volumes being $2V$ and $V$. Consider the following statements:


- I.A greater mass was used than substance BII.It has a lower energy density than substance BIII.It provided the same amount of energy as substance B

Which statement is/are correct for substance A and the amount of it used in the time period?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ III only
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ I, II, and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The mass of substances can be determined by multiplying their density and volume, ensuring their masses are equal. Since both substances provide the same average of power over the same time, they provide the same amount of energy. ($E=Pt$)
Energy density can be calculated by


- Energy density = $\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}$

While both provide the same amount of energy, Substance B has a smaller volume compared to Substance A. Consequently, Substance A possesses a lower energy density.

title: Question 24
content:
A boat is traveling along a straight line for a total time of one hour. The boat travels at a constant speed and covers a total distance of 2.4 km. The thrust of the boat's engine is 1.8 kN.
What is the energy exerted by the boat's engine in one second?


- A. $\hspace{1em} $ 0.67 kJ
- B. $\hspace{1em} $ 1.2 kJ
- C. $\hspace{1em} $ 4.3 kJ
- D. $\hspace{1em} $ 78 kJ
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $P = \dfrac{E}{t}$

so energy exerted in one second is the same as power.


- $P = Fv$



- $v = 2.4$ km h$^{-1} = 2.4(1000$ m)(3600 s)$^{-1}$ = $\dfrac{2400\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}} = \dfrac{2}{3}$  m s$^{-1}$



- $P = (1.8$ kN)$\bigg(\dfrac{2}{3}$ m s$^{-1}\bigg)$ = 1.2 kW

Therefore the energy exerted in one second is 1.2 kJ.

title: Question 25
content:
A box of mass 2.0 kg starts to move on a level surface under the effect of a varying net force $F$. The variation of $F$ with the displacement $s$ of the object is shown in the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4bfc368-0267-49cf-8736-1f84399bfb17/images/203a8d73-301e-4840-b6e9-aede11252de9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.12.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the speed of the box at s = 5 m?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $5 m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{5}$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	1$5 m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{15}$ m s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The work done $W$ by the $F$ on the box equals the change in kinetic energy $\Delta E_k$ of the box and work done can be found by calculating the area under the graph, the area between the line and the displacement axis.


- $W=\Delta E_k \hspace{2em}$     and   $\hspace{2em} W=$ Area of the graph
- $\Delta E_k=$ Area of the graph (using trapezond formula)
- $\dfrac{1}{2}\left(2\right)v^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+2)(5)$
- $v^2=25$
- $v=5\, $m$\,$s$^{-1}$

Alternatively, we can treat the area as a rectangle and a triangle.


- $\Delta E_k=$ Area of the graph (using rectangle and triangle)
- $\dfrac{1}{2}\left(2\right)v^2=(2)(5)+\dfrac{1}{2}(6)(5)$
- $v^2=25$
- $v=5\, $m$\,$s$^{-1}$

title: Question 26
content:
A varying force acts on a spring. The variation of the extension $x$ of the spring with force $F$ acting on it is shown in the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec27ecb3-2d0f-45e3-9076-c10b42685391/images/77ac9eb1-21af-49dc-951a-c2d213bf94cb/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2011.51.09%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $E$ when the extension of the spring is $e$. What is the work done by force on the spring to increase the extension from $e$ to $3e$ ?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  2E$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	4E$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	8E$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	9E$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $E$ when it is stretched by $e$;


- $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}ke^2$  where $k$ is the spring constant of the spring

The elastic potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched by $3e$ can be found  as;


- $E_{Hfinal}=\dfrac{1}{2}k{(3e)}^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k{9e}^2=9E$

The work done on the spring can be found by calculating the change in the elastic potential energy $\Delta E_H$ of the spring.


- $\mathrm{\Delta}E_H=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(final)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(initial\right)}$
- $\mathrm{\Delta}E_H=9E-E=8E$

Therefore, the answer is C.

title: Question 28
content: An elastic bungee cord of natural length $20$ m is being tested. A spherical object, originally at rest, is released from a platform. Air resistance and the mass of the cord are insignificant. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/08604633-fc44-4b7b-b6e7-ff05446ce89d/PH0644-000.png) - State the principle of conservation of energy. [2] - Describe the energy changes that take place in the spherical object from the time it is released until it comes to rest for the first time. [2] - Show that the speed of the object just before the cord starts to extend is approximately $20$ m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The magnitude of the average $\underline{\textrm{net}}$ force acting on the object between the point where the cord starts to extend and the point where it reaches maximum extension is $360$ N. The time taken during the fall of the object between these points is $0.28$ s. - Show that the mass of the object is approximately $5.0$ kg. [2] - On the graph below, sketch how the the elastic potential energy $E_{H}$ of the spring changes with the vertical displacement $s$ as the cord stretches. There is no need to add values to the axes. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/a3f03b0a-9936-43ec-b0e8-351bd0ef3d31/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.28.03%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - The extension of the cord at the point in time when the object has zero acceleration is $11$ m. Determine the spring constant of the cord. [2]
markScheme:
- (in any process) energy is neither created nor destroyed $\checkmark$
  It can only be transformed from one form into another. $\checkmark$
  
- The gravitational potential energy of the object is converted to the kinetic energy of the object. $\checkmark$
  The kinetic and gravitational potential energy of the object are converted into elastic potential energy within the cord. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When it is released, its gravitational potential energy is converted to kinetic energy due to the decrease in height above the ground. As soon as the centre of mass of the object has fallen by $20$ m, the cord starts to extend and store elastic potential energy. As it comes to rest, the object's kinetic and gravitational potential energy are converted to the elastic potential energy of the cord.
  
- 
  
  - $mg \Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$ $\checkmark$
  - $v=\answer{19.8\ \ce{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The decrease in height of the object is $20$ m. Its decrease in gravitational potential energy equals the increase in kinetic energy.
  
  
  - $mg\Delta h= \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{2g\Delta h}$
  - $v=\sqrt{(2)(9.81)(20)}$
  - $v=19.8$ m s$^{-1}$

  Alternatively,
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$
  - $v^2=0^2+2(-9.81)(-20)$
  - $v=19.8$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- 
  - 
    
    - $F_{avg}\Delta t=\Delta p$ $\checkmark$
    - $m = \answer{5.04\ \ce{kg} }\ \checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The object is stationary and has zero momentum when the cord has maximum extension. By using impulse = change in momentum;
    $\begin{aligned}
      F_{avg}\Delta t&=\Delta p\\
      (360)(0.28)&=m(19.8)\\
      100.8&=m(19.8)\\
      m&=\dfrac{100.8}{19.8}\\
      m&=5.09\textrm{ kg}\\
      \end{aligned}$
    
  - $\hspace{2em}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/91a2589c-b619-4d71-90f8-2a7948064acb/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.32.17%E2%80%AF0AM.JPEG)


    Parabolic graph with positive gradient. $\checkmark$
    Passes through origin. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The elastic potential energy stored in the cord is proportional to the square of the extension. Since the force acting on the cord is downwards due to the weight of the object, the vertical displacement of the object s as the cord starts to extend equals the extension x of the cord.
    
    
    - $s^2\propto x^2\propto E_{H}$

    This relationship can be represented by a graph in the shape of
    
    
    - $y=x^2$

    
  - Weight of the object = force of the spring on the object/$W=kx$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $k=\dfrac{W}{x} = \dfrac{49}{11}$
    - $k=\answer{4.5\ \ce{ N m}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The forces acting on the object are the weight of the object and the force of spring on the object. When the object has no acceleration, these two forces are balanced by each other. The weight of the object;
    
    
    - $W=mg=\left(5.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=49$ N

    By using Hooke's Law:
    
    
    - $F=kx$
    - $k=\dfrac{F}{x}$
    - $k=\dfrac{49}{11}$
    - $k=4.5$ N m$^{-1}$

title: Question 29
content:
A natural gas plant burns fuel with a specific energy of 80 MJ kg$^{-1}$.
The rate of energy input of the natural gas is 1.6 GW. What is the rate at which the fuel burns?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.0005 kg s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 kg s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 1500 kg s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 20 kg s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The energy delivered per second (power) will be equal to the product of the mass burning rate and the specific energy.
Therefore,


- $\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}(80\textrm{ MJ kg}^{-1})=1.6$ GW
- $\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{1.6\times10^9\textrm{ J s}^{-1}}{8.0\times10^7\textrm{ J kg}^{-1}}=20$ kg s$^{-1}$

title: Question 31
content:
A car is moving with a kinetic energy of ${10}^5$ J.
Estimate the order of magnitude of its momemtum.


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^3$ kg m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^4$ kg m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^5$ kg m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^6$ kg m s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The relationship between kinetic energy $E_k$ and momentum $p$ of the car is given by the following formula:


- $E_k=\dfrac{p^2}{2m}$
- $p^2=2mE_k$

The order of magnitude of the mass of a car is ${10}^3\, kg$.


- $p^2\approx 2\left({10}^3\right)\left({10}^5\right)$
- $p^2\approx{10}^8 $
- $p\approx{10}^4$

title: Question 37
content:
A ball with mass $m$ is released from a height of $h$ and undergoes free fall. The ball hits the ground and rebounds vertically. On rebound, the ball reaches a maximum height of $h'$. The time taken for the collision is $T$. During the collision, what are the change in kinetic energy of the ball and the magnitude of the average net force on the ball?

$\hspace{1em}$ Change in kinetic energy $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1em}$ Average force $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h-h')$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h'-h)$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h'-h)$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h-h')$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in kinetic energy  = Loss of mechanical energy = change in potential energy


- = $mgh' - mgh = mg(h'-h)$

We can find the velocity before hitting the ground using conservation of energy


- $\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2=mgh$

giving


- $u = \sqrt{2gh}$

Similarly, velocity after bouncing from the ground


- $v = - \sqrt{2gh'}$

Change in momentum


- $\Delta p = m (v-u)$ = $m (-\sqrt{2gh'} - \sqrt{2gh})$

Force is rate of change of momentum


- $F_{av} = \dfrac{-m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$

Because the question asks for the magnitude of the average force, we can take the positive value.


- $F_{av} = \dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$

title: Question 39
content:
A ball is released from rest at a height $h$ above the ground. At each bounce 75% of its kinetic energy is lost. Which graph represents the variation of the ball's velocity $v$ with time $t$ from the beginning of motion until the moment just before the third bounce? Assume the acceleration of the ball is in in the negative direction and that air resistance is negligible.

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/a516a5f2-3a03-4885-811d-0da67b6ad48e/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.14%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/c52e4b88-650f-407b-aa7e-ecf2ab94b5f1/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.26%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/f9d6effd-a838-49ed-b769-1e65f233ace2/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/75cb8fb0-e10e-4e0e-b129-422f1813f50d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Kinetic energy $E_k$ is directly proportional to the square of the magnitude of velocity $v$


- $E_k = \dfrac{1}{2} mv^2$

The velocity will decrease to half of its value at each bounce.
The value of the acceleration is constant, free fall acceleration $g$. The velocity time graph should be linear and all sections should have a negative gradient to represent downwards acceleration.
The direction of velocity is positive on the way up, and negative on the way down.

title: Question 46
content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energy $E_p$ when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
In terms of $E_p$, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$E_p$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $E_p$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$E_p$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.25$E_p$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Using Hooke's law,


- $F=k\Delta x$

the elastic potential energy is


- $E_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta x$.

In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equation


- $F=k\Delta x$.

When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

title: Question 58
content:
Two masses of $2$ kg and $4$ kg are connected with a string that passes over a pulley. They are released from rest. Energy is lost in the pulley due to friction.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a3935bc0-26a9-423f-98b1-8976d18dc4d7/images/ba606c7f-40fe-40a9-9904-adf078fef49f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.43.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When the $2$ kg mass has gained a gravitational potential energy of $E$, the $4$ kg mass has a kinetic energy of $\dfrac{1}{2}E$. How much energy has been lost to friction up to that point in time?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{4}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	E$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	2E$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since both of the masses are connected by the string, they should have the same speed and vertical displacement.
Because both $E_p$ and $E_k$ are proportional to the mass of the object,
Gravitational potential energy loss of the mass of $4$ kg will be twice the gain of the small mass, which would be $2E$
Similarly, the kinetic energy of the mass of $2\, kg$ will be half of that of the $4\,kg$ which gives $\dfrac{E}{4}$
Due to the principle of energy conservation;
The potential energy lost by the mass of  $4$ kg is equal to the sum of


- The potential energy gained by the mass of $2$ kg $(2E)$
- energy lost due to friction $(U)$
- kinetic energy of the mass of $2$ kg $\bigg(\dfrac{E}{4}\bigg)$ and $4$ kg $\bigg(\dfrac{E}{2}\bigg)$



- $2E\ =E+U+\dfrac{E}{4}+\dfrac{E}{2}$
- $U=\dfrac{E}{4}$

title: Question 59
content:
A metal ball of mass $m$ is released from a height of $h$ above a massless platform attached to a vertical spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b5cb7aae-5a20-4225-b7e7-576050644152/images/83f09acf-9277-45e6-9188-189b131b1bb6/PH0565.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}$
The spring constant of the spring is given by $\dfrac{mg}{h}$. The ball hits the spring and compresses it. When the spring is compressed by a distance $h$, what is the speed of the ball?
(Energy transfer only happens between spring and ball and the kinetic energy of the spring can be ignored)


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2h}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2gh}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{3h}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{3gh}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When the initial position and final position of the ball are compared in terms of energy, it can be realized that the decrease in gravitational potential energy $E_p$ of the ball equals to increase in kinetic energy $E_{k}$ of the ball and the increase in elastic potential energy $E_H$ of the spring. Additionally, the total decrease in height of the ball is $2h$.
$\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_p&=E_k +E_H\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mg(2h)&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2+\frac{1}{2}\frac{mg}{h}h^2 \\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\frac{1}{2}mv^2&=mg(2h)-\frac{1}{2}mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=4mgh-mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=3mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
v&=\sqrt{3gh}\\
\end{aligned}$
Therefore, the answer is D.

title: Question 60
content: - Define potential energy. [1] - A body of mass 2.0 kg is pushed with an initial speed of 1.2 m s$^{-1}$ down the slope of a frictionless 30$\degree$ incline from a height of $h$. As soon as it reaches the bottom of the incline, it begins to move on a rough horizontal table where it comes to rest momentarily after colliding with a spring of spring constant 32 N m$^{-1}$. (Air friction is ignored) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8235c2b-58f5-4ef1-b323-f3a1908362b0/images/f4457c50-c03d-4ce6-8c85-95822296a5f5/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.38.19%E2%80%AFPM.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$ - The speed of the body is 3.06 m s$^{-1}$ when it reaches the bottom of the incline. Calculate $h$. [2] - The distance between the bottom of the slope and the body's position is $x$. On the graph, sketch the variation of the square of the speed $v^2$ of the body with distance $x$ from the bottom of the slope. [2] (no need to add values to the axes) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8235c2b-58f5-4ef1-b323-f3a1908362b0/images/259e6e21-40a1-43ae-a7ea-d3ed5221df9d/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.21.26%E2%80%AFPM.png) - At the instant that the body stops momentarily, the spring is compressed as 0.43 m. The coefficient of friction between the body and the rough surface is 0.40. Determine the distance that the body covered on the horizontal rough surface between the point of leaving the ramp and stopping momentarily. [4] - The incline is replaced with one of a steeper gradient. The body is pushed at the same speed from the same height. Explain the effect of the increase in gradient on the maximum compression of the spring in comparison to the maximum compression in the original situation. [2]
markScheme:
- The energy possessed by the system due to the relative positions of its components or parts OR energy possessed by an object due to its position in a field $\checkmark$



- 
  - Use of conservation of energy $\checkmark$
    $h = \ll \dfrac{1}{2g}(v^2-u^2) = \gg$ $0.40$ m $\checkmark$
    (also allow use of forces and acceration to achieve the same result)
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The energy of the body $E_i$ at the beginning is the sum of the kinetic energy $E_{ki}$ and the difference in the potential energy $\Delta E_p$  between the starting point and the bottom of the incline;
    
    
    - $E_i = E_{ki} + \Delta E_p = \dfrac{1}{2}mu^2 + mgh \hspace{1em}$ where $u = 1.2$ m s$^{-1}$ and $m = 2.0$ kg

    The energy $E_f$ when the body reaches the rough surface equals the kinetic energy $E_{kf}$ due to the final speed;
    
    
    - $E_f = E_{kf} = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$ where $v=3.06$ m s$^{-1}$ and $m=2$ kg

    The incline is frictionless and there is no air friction. Therefore, the total energy must be conserved throughout the motion.
    $\begin{aligned}
      E_i &= E_f\\
      \hspace{2.3cm}\\
      \frac{1}{2}mu^2 + mgh &= \frac{1}{2}mv^2\\      
      \hspace{2.3cm}\\
      \frac{1}{2}u^2 + gh &= \frac{1}{2}v^2\\      
      \hspace{2.3cm}\\
      gh &= \frac{1}{2}v^2 - \frac{1}{2}u^2\\      
      \hspace{2.3cm}\\
      h &= \frac{1}{2g}(v^2-u^2)\\
      \end{aligned}$
    when the given values are substituted in the equation;
    
    
    - $h = \dfrac{1}{(2)(9.81)}(3.06^2 - 1.2^2) = 0.40$ m


  
  
  - $\textrm{ }$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8235c2b-58f5-4ef1-b323-f3a1908362b0/images/42d6466e-d66e-4619-9b23-3288d3daf221/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.22.42%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    A straight line with a non-zero minimum value of $v^2$ at $x=$max $\checkmark$
    negative gradient $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The height of the body at any position can be expressed as;
    
    
    - $h=x\sin\theta$

    The sum of gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy of the body is constant for every position of the body on the incline;
    
    
    - $E_{tot} = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgx\sin\theta$ where $c$ is a constant.

    Is can be rearranged as;
    
    
    - $E_{tot} - mgx\sin\theta = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
    - $v^2=\dfrac{2E_{tot}}{m} - 2gx\sin\theta$ where $\dfrac{2E_{tot}}{m}$ and $2g\sin\theta$ are constant

    This relationship is similar to the following expression:
    
    
    - $y=mx + C$ where $C=\dfrac{2E_{tot}}{m}$, $m=-2g\sin\theta$, $x = x$ and $y = v^2$

    Therefore, the relationship between $x$ and $v^2$ can be expressed with a straight line that starts from a non-zero value and has a negative gradient.
    
  - Change in energy in the spring = $\ll \dfrac{1}{2}(32)(0.43)^2 = \gg 3.0$ J $\checkmark$
    Energy difference/lost = $\ll \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(3.06)^2 - 3.0 = \gg - 6.4$ J $\checkmark$
    Work done = $\ll$ Friction = $\mu mg\cos\theta d = (0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(-1) \gg - 7.8\,d\,\checkmark$
    $d=$ $0.82$ m $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The change in energy between the time at which the body starts to move on the rough surface and stops momentarily is the difference between the kinetic energy $E_{Ki}$ of the body and the elastic potential energy of the spring $E_{pi}$;
    
    
    - $\Delta E = E_{Ki} - E_{Pi}$
    - $\Delta E = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2$ where $v = 3.06$ m s$^{-1}$, $m=2.0$ kg, $k=32$ N m$^{-1}$ and $x = 0.43$
    - $\Delta E = \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(3.06)^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}(32)(0.43)^2=6.4$ J

    Work is done by the friction force $F_f$ on the body for a distance $d$;
    
    
    - $W = F_fd\cos\theta = \mu Nd\cos\theta = \mu mgd\cos\theta$

    where
    
    
    - $\mu = 0.40,\,\theta = 180°$
    - $W = (0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d (-1) = -7.8d$

    The work done $W$ acting on the system equals the change in energy $\Delta E$
    
    
    - $W = \Delta E$
    - $-7.8\,d = -6.4$ J
    - $d = \dfrac{-6.4}{-7.8} = 0.82$ m

    

- No change/same $\checkmark$
  The initial total energy of the body is same with previous alignment $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The initial total energy of the body $E$
  
  
  - $E = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh$

  None of the quantities above is changed. So the initial total energy is the same as the previous situation.
  The initial total energy of the body equals the sum of elastic potential energy $E_p$ and the magnitude of work done by friction $W$;
  
  
  - $E = E_p + W$
  - $E = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2 + \mu mgd$

  None of the quantities above is changed with the angle of the incline. Hence, compression does not change.

title: Question 61
content:
A 74 kg boy starts to ride a 6.0 kg bicycle from rest. The graph shows how the acceleration $a$ of the bicycle varies with the distance travelled $x$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d4d2c1c2-6eda-4118-be39-9118e7b4d664/images/66c0c029-7c83-49ce-91c5-fb1a477bf51b/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%208.49.04%E2%80%AFAM.png)


What is the total work done by the boy?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.3 kJ
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 3.7 kJ
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 4.0 kJ
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 6.0 kJ
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Work Done = (Force $\times$ Distance) = (Mass $\times$ Acceleration $\times$ Distance)
(Acceleration $\times$ Distance) is the area under the graph.
Work done is (Mass $\times$ Graph Area) = (74+6)(50) = 4000 J = 4 kJ

title: Question 62
content:
An object of mass $1.0$ kg rests on a rough surface. Another object of mass $2.0$ kg is connected to it with a string.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/5ad23e85-206e-4711-b2ed-20c0481d45a3/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.53.49%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When the objects are released, the masses accelerate at $\dfrac{g}{2}$. The work done by the tension of the string on the $1.0$ kg mass is $40$ J. Which of the following is correct for the $1.0$ kg mass during this period?

Magnitude of the force of friction / NDistance travelled / m$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$10$4.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$5$4.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$10$2.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$5$2.0$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The acceleration is given as $\dfrac{g}{2}$ which is equal to $\dfrac{10}{2} = 5$ m s$^{-2}$
The free body diagram of the forces on the mass of $2.0$ kg:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/c2d6f4fb-acd4-4d56-a0c4-8def2c43d211/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.45%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


According to Newton's second law, the relationship between tension $T$, the weight of the object $W$ and the acceleration of the object:
$\begin{aligned}
F_{net}&=ma\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
W_2-T&=(2.0)(5)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
(2)(10)-T&=(2.0)(5)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T&=10\textrm{ N}\\
\end{aligned}$
The free body diagram of the forces on the mass of $1.0$ kg:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/60248a9f-84bf-4dfd-b06e-48f3db63eec5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.51%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The normal reaction force $F_N$ of the ground on the box balances the weight $W$ of the object. According to Newton's second law, the relationship between Tension $T$, the force of friction on the object $F_f$ and the acceleration of the object


- $T-F_f=(1.0)(5)$

When the magnitude of $T$ is substituted in the equation;


- $10-F_f=(1.0)(5)$
- $\hspace{2em}F_f=5$ N

The work done $W$ by $T$ can be found by the product of $T$ and the distance $d$ travelled by the object.


- $W_1=Td$
- $40=10d$
- $d=4.0$ m
